item.title: First content live
item.description: After years of dithering and pussy footing around about where to publish my economic justice writing, I settled on this github repository… because… free-libre nerd. I’m not out to build a following or anything like that, but just want activist-geeks (a non-vanishing class of people) to have some decent software to use that won’t be a perennial pain-in-the you-know-what for GNU+Linux users to install (last version of Minsky would not build from tarball nor run even when installed successfully from the Debian repo — I think Keen and hpcoder have achieved code bloat).

item.title: Ōhanga Pai Projects Overview
item.description: Overview of the Projects Asset Exchange Models These are pretty simple models in the class of “econophysics ”. They are agent-based models, and show the basic wealth distributions that occur generically given some rules for how entities (individuals or units like small firms) exchange assets. These models are great for thinking about fair distribution policies, which at a government regulatory level means fiscal policy. The models show that highly unfair wealth distributions naturally occur even when asset exchanges are uniform and random.

item.title: Introduction to Ōhanga Pai
item.description: These are raw journal entries. An Ōhanga Pai hackers journal. For specific content articles in chapter format see Philosophy or Empirical sections. We’ve got a few projects on-the-go. Asset exchange models (Drăgulescu–Ispolatov–Yakovenko models) Keen–Goodwin models in python (pymsky project) Job Guarantee models in the Keen–Goodwin framework. Econometric analysis of the central bank interest rate policy — are interest rate hikes inflationary in the short run? (Interest–income and forward pricing channels overwhelm the propensity to save/borrow discriminants).

item.title: Ōhanga Pai Projects Introduction
item.description: This section is for discussions (in article form) of theory and empirical research development. Contributors are welcome, but will need to submit through the Contact form. Your article needs to be technical, not philosophical. The philosophy and questions section of this website goes through in a breezy way some of the concepts and possible avenues of research for the Ōhanga Pai community. This section of articles gives you just a little taste of some projects I might be working on, time and willing collaborators permitting.

item.title: Basic MMT and Economic Justice
item.description: For most of this whole course on MMT I am going to use the example of New Zealand, since many people claim MMT only applies to a country like the USA which enjoys a global reserve currency status. This would be false. MMT applies perfectly well to a small open economy like New Zealand. The currency is the NZD. item.title: Introduction to Ōhanga Pai Q&A
item.description: This section Questions is for mostly philosophical discussions (in article form). Main topics include macroeconomics, economic justice, the Job Guarantee policy and fiscal versus monetary policy. For public banking (really just banking in general) I’ve drawn heavily upon the prior work of Warren Mosler, Randall Wray, and Eric Tymoigne. For employment issues I draw on Mosler again, and Bill Mitchell & Pavlina Tcherneva . For popular macroeconomics discourse I rely upon Money on the Left and Stephanie Kelton @Market Watch.
